item.description:
The details continue to show a hesitant but not overly concerned consumer.

In June, the Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index fell modestly to 100.4 from a downwardly revised 101.3 the previous month. That's despite lower petrol prices in early June and the S&P 500 reaching a record high in the days leading up to this month's survey deadline. The report was about as mixed as it could be.

Income expectations fell, vacation plans increased, and households' perceptions of the labour market and business conditions remained largely unchanged. All of this resulted in a fairly stable confidence reading, as evidenced by the chart, which showed it remaining within its recent narrow range.

Average 12-month inflation expectations ticked up from 5.3% to 5.4%.
